"When I was young my father said to me: ‚ÄúKnowledge is power, Francis Bacon.‚Äù I understood it as ‚ÄúKnowledge is power, France is bacon.‚Äù

For more than a decade I wondered over the meaning of the second part and what was the surreal linkage between the two. If I said the quote to someone, ‚ÄúKnowledge is power, France is Bacon,‚Äù they nodded knowingly. Or someone might say, ‚ÄúKnowledge is power‚Äù and I‚Äôd finish the quote ‚ÄúFrance is bacon,‚Äù and they wouldn‚Äôt look at me like I‚Äôd said something very odd, but thoughtfully agree. I did ask a teacher what did ‚ÄúKnowledge is power, France is bacon‚Äù mean and got a full 10-minute explanation of the ‚Äúknowledge is power‚Äù bit but nothing on ‚ÄúFrance is bacon.‚Äù When I prompted further explanation by saying ‚ÄúFrance is bacon?‚Äù in a questioning tone, I just got a ‚Äúyes.‚Äù At 12 I didn‚Äôt have the confidence to press it further. I just accepted it as something I‚Äôd never understand.

It wasn‚Äôt until years later I saw it written down that the penny dropped."

And now for a nit. 15A. 

An ADREP is not a [Campaign manager] even with a [?] 

An ADREP works for the medium and sells space or time. A media buyer at the ad agency buys the space or time. An ad "campaign" is "managed" by an account executive at the ad agency. There have been fine clues for ADREP. This incorrect clue appeared once before, in 2012. It should be retired.

Thank you.

On foggy mornings, Charlotte's web was truly a thing of beauty. This morning each thin strand was decorated with dozens of tiny beads of water. The web glistened in the light and made a pattern of loveliness and mystery, like a delicate veil. Even Lurvy, who wasn't particularly interested in beauty, noticed the web when he came with the pig's breakfast. He noted how clearly it showed up and he noted how big and carefully built it was. And then he took another look and he saw something that made him set his pail down. There, in the center of the web, neatly woven in block letters, was a message. It said: 

                                        SOME PIG

Lurvy felt weak. He brushed his hand across his eyes and stared harder at Charlotte's web. 

"I'm seeing things," he whispered. He dropped to his knees and uttered a short prayer. Then, forgetting all about Wilbur's breakfast, he walked back to the house and called Mr. Zuckerman.

"I think you'd better come down to the pigpen," he said.

"What's the trouble?" asked Mr. Zuckerman. "Anything wrong with the pig?"

"N-not exactly," said Lurvy. "Come and see for yourself." 

The two men walked silently down to Wilbur's yard. Lurvy pointed to the spider's web. "Do you see what I see?" he asked.

Zuckerman stared at the writing on the web. Then he murmured the words "Some Pig." Then he looked at Lurvy. Then they both began to tremble. Charlotte, sleepy after her night's exertions, smiled as she watched.

(From Charlotte's Web)

I enjoyed the puzzle, but crosses were essential. Some of the more arcane clues I knew, e.g., SLOAN (Ash Can School of American Art) and HANS Castorp (Mann's "Magic Mountain") because they were acquired before my brain became so porous. Less sticks these days, and who knows, I may have heard of that Eurodance hit, and just forgot it (oh right).  

In any case, I had a good time and found the grid to be Sunday worthy. Thank you, Natan.

This piggy themed puzzle is certainly au courant.  I‚Äôm not one who hates general knowledge/trivia in puzzles as a rule, but this one had ALOT. Thanks to the theme, and other swine adjacent clues, I didn‚Äôt find it boaring, and the unknowns were easy enough to get via crosses.  In fact it was a tad easier than I‚Äôd like.  But in the end I decided THATLLDO.

Now if I‚Äôd been constructing the puzzle I might have slipped in a couple of musical references, such as sixties folk/rock band Pearls Before Swine, and sixties blues/rock band Blodwyn Pig, or something about Linda Ronstadt‚Äôs album, Silk Purse, the cover of which features the singer posing in a pig sty.  Fortunately for all of you, I‚Äôm no puzzle constructor.

Got me thinking about Miss Piggy, whose signature accessory is a pearl necklace.

I did find the revealer a bit self-evident, which helped me to catch on to the pattern in the other four themed columns more quickly and shave 16+ minutes off my average Sunday. But I found that exciting, rather than disappointing! I guess some folks are just hard to please.

I was glad to see Frank O‚ÄôHara and Mart√≠n Espada, the latter of whom I was unfamiliar with but now I‚Äôm not, which is the kind of nudge I appreciate from my grid. In the same vein, I was disappointed to see playwright David Mamet get snubbed in favor of his actress daughter Zosia.

VAMP might have meant freeform improvisation in 1789, as your dictionary cites. But in the modern music world, it has the opposite meaning from ‚Äúnoodling‚Äú‚Äî it‚Äôs a fixed pattern that can be repeated without variation in preparation for a solo entrance.

Well, themes don‚Äôt get any tighter than this.
I solved pretty much from left to right rather than up to down, and as I was getting toward the revealer, I was thinking ‚Äúare there lipstick colors of JAM and ONION and BUCK?‚Äù (I‚Äôm sure most of you will get my reference, if not c.f. the 2008 presidential election).
Anyway, this is one of those grids where I will admit that the fill is definitely a little Naticky in a few spots and and the clues a little bit tortuous‚Äînot my favorite‚Äîbut in the service of a very unusual theme, that required a lot of construction magic and sweat‚Äîmore than satisfying in the end, for me at least. The theme was IRKSOME for me - it relied too much on factual knowledge, and even though I got and understood the revealer, I needed the column to explain everything to me in detail. I always think if it takes an essay to explain a theme, there is something wrong with it...

I found the fill largely gettable, with the exception of the two bottom corner areas.

In the SW quadrant I needed lookups because of the intertwined NIH/RICO/LOOIE (looie? That must be a lieutenant, but I've never seen or heard the tem, or at least remembered it), and SCRIM/OHARA/RARITAN. I was also so sure of MAYHaM being spelled that way I never checked the cross (it was sport-related, and I always ignore those as I virtually never know them, anyway), and in the end I only resolved this by checking the puzzle.

In the SE corner I was stumped by two things. First: VAMPING and its clue. I have no idea what noodling may refer to, and even though VAMPING is mentioned in the column, and a dictionary entry has been linked there, I apparently know too little about making jazz music to get any of it. It's like a description of a cricket match - it sort of looks like it's in English, but I have no idea what's going on.

Second, greasy spoon solving to EATERY. Ok... I could google it, but please indulge me and elaborate below - I'd rather learn about this from the community.

A splendid puzzle. 

Minor correction to the column. Novae are eruptions on the surfaces of white dwarfs, but a white dwarf isn‚Äôt a collapsed star. 

That‚Äôd be a neutron star and in that case the ‚Äúflare up‚Äù would be a supernova.
SO SWEET that the answers included THATLL DO

I once had a dog named Will who loved to eat. His nickname was Wilbur because he was Some Pig. (He was also Terrific, and often Radiant.)

I was a bit stymied over a bank of obscure clues, but I‚Äôm not so pig-headed that I didn‚Äôt enjoy the theme. Was it inspired by leftover Thanksgiving ham? Or just a desire to make us all go hog wild? Either way, I‚Äôm as happy as a pig in mud. (Leave me alone while I enjoy my truffles.)

When I saw the Pearls Before Swine, could help thinking of he song I Am the Highway by Audioslave. One of the most moving songs and videos if you get a chance to hear:

Long and weary my road has been
I was lost in the cities

No sorrow or pity for leaving, I feel, yeah

Not sure why I didn‚Äôt recall the idiom don‚Äôt cast PEARLS BEFORE SWINE before?! It filled in easily enough. I got all of the PEARLs (ONION, JAM, BUCK and HARBOR) as well as the SWINE (PORKY, HAMM, WILBUR and BABE). I had heard from my S-I-L the phrase ‚Äúonly swine dine before nine‚Äù when we would visit her in NY. She would make our dinner reservations for 9:30 pm and I was aghast as a west coaster. It was like eating after midnight to me ü§£ The horror! Anyway, I had one typo at the end. I had LOuIE, but in going through the downs, I knew it should be RICO, so worked itself out. Nice ending to a great holiday week. Fingers crossed that I don‚Äôt get selected for jury duty tomorrow ü§ûüèº I‚Äôve only been called for Federal jury duty and selected both times. This time is California state Superior Court. My first jury experience was an international drug smuggling case with Armenian mob ties. The defendant‚Äôs family showed up toward the end and armed guards were added to the courtroom. Jury members had to be escorted to their vehicles. It was extremely unnerving to say the least. This experience is why I‚Äôm not a fan of jury duty üò¨

Very fun puzzle that (depending on whose stats I trust) is either my fastest Sunday ever or my fifth fastest. But I think I was done with the grid before the PEARLS made sense. Much as I enjoy the Dorothy Parker anecdote, it may be apocryphal: https://quoteinvestigator.com/2011/06/29/pearls-before-swine/ Congratulations on your book, Natan! I‚Äôm only about 60 pages into it, but it‚Äôs informative and entertaining.
The porcine theme reminds me of possibly the greatest newspaper correction of all time‚Ä¶ https://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=2951

Authentic Beijing duck is not served with Hoisin sauce. It‚Äôs served with a fermented sauce made from wheat flour, called Tian Mian Sauce. 

Hoisin sauce is from Canton, and used to serve Beijing duck with in Chinatown Cantonese restaurants, most likely because Tian Mian sauce wasn‚Äôt available.

I got the theme fairly quickly, but got stuck on a few items that took a long time and a lot of crosses to get. Finally finished without help, and really marvel and the great construction. Natan Last's puzzles never disappoint!

One thing that shouldn't have slowed me down was 96A. I lived within spitting distance of the Raritan River in NJ for 25 years! But it took a couple of crosses till I got it. Yikes!

Never heard of Zosia Mamet, so I figured she was probably David Mamet's daughter. That sent me to Wikipedia. Unfortunately, I read the whole entry, which at the end made me wince from the description of his political leanings. Gotta stop going down these rabbit holes.
Does no one realize that "Do not cast your pearls before swine" is spoken by Jesus during the Sermon on the Mount? (Matthew 7:6)  An idiom? Maybe, but originally it is a metaphor.

Whenever I think of pigs, I imagine them with the contented smiles that often show up on their faces, and my whole being calms and feels happy.

That warm fuzzy feeling also accompanied my solve.  There were sticky areas that I couldn‚Äôt crack, but I somehow knew I eventually would.  Throughout the fill-in I felt engaged and interested, never frustrated.  It‚Äôs actually my favorite part of this puzzle ‚Äì how I felt while solving it.

There‚Äôs an art to creating that sweet spot.

That‚Äôs on top of the science.  Look at how tight this theme is, due to the PEARL element.  Aside from ‚Äúbarley‚Äù, ‚ÄúBailey‚Äù, and ‚Äúdiver‚Äù, what other possibilities are there for the circled words?  Despite this, Natan found theme answers to fit symmetry, all the while fitting them in a sorta image of a pig made out of the black squares.  Wow!

Anyway, this puzzle was made by a pro.  Natan, I loved this ‚Äì thank you!
Lovely puzzle. Loved the additional Babe nod at 36A with THATLLDO, a saying that gets a lot of play in our house.
BTW, speaking of pearls before swine, the former showed up on earth about half a billion years prior to the latter.

Pretty much a game of two halves for me. Most of the theme clues were gimmes, except WILBUR. I know there was a film but I don‚Äôt think the book was much of a hit in the UK.  Not while my lot were small anyway.

There were some great clues; I‚Äôm a huge fan of Frank O‚ÄôHARA, frequently dipping into his completed works.  While there was an awful lot I didn‚Äôt know, including most of the small, gluey fill, there was much to like; CLOBBERED, VAMPING and MAYHEM for some.

Recovering from a major bout of Christmas shopping yesterday. Actual, fighting the crowds, the rain and the cold sort of shopping. I‚Äôve given up on the online variety,  as the designated carrier in our area for pretty much every company  is an absolute shambles. Average delivery from despatch is up to two weeks. If it arrives at all. Naturally there is no method of communication to lodge a complaint with. I‚Äôve told all the sites I use most that I will no longer shop with them due to the poor delivery record. Not that they‚Äôll care but hey, I have to start somewhere.

There are two clues in here that I find IRKSOME every time I open up the crossword

The various possible spellings of bok CHOY - bok vs pok vs pak vs bak and CHOY vs CHOi. And I believe Australia uses puk for one of the varieties. 

And HON vs HuN. Though this last one is the Brit/Irish in me. HON being short for Honey, but on this side of the pond is written Hun. Similar to St Patrick being shortened to Patty stateside and Paddy over here.

Reminds me of the lucky dip of tsar vs czar.

But... the varied implied meanings of 'Pearl' in each of the referenced down answers was quite clever. Must have taken a LOT of pondering to come up with something like this.

This was a great solve, beginning to end, across and down. My experience solving it was unusual. Woke up early, couldn't fall back to sleep, so thought I'd do the Monday puzzle. Why did I think that? Well, dog injured last Monday, followed 6 hrs in vet e.r. Wednesday, cooked all day Thursday, nsaids prescribed for dog led to diarrhea since Friday. He's doing better, but I'm exhausted. Here's the curveball: my thinking still that this was a Monday puzzle until reading comments here probably led to one of my fastest Sunday solves. ü§ûpup continues to recover.

You don't eat Peking duck with hoisin sauce. Peking duck is meant to be accompanied by something called tian mian sauce. Some other varieties of Chinese roast duck age served with hoisin, but Peking duck is something specific.

The proper names (all mysteries to me) and concepts such as Eurodance...not helpful!!...made this more difficult (whereas otherwise I thought the entries were pretty simple.)

My favorite thing was the 77D clue, " Literary runt of the litter," because it salutes an absolutely wonderful book, the last line of which is poignant and true.  

Hats off to Natan Last!
Liked everything but LOUD OUT. felt like a seventh inning stretch to get that answer.

The Day Lady Died
By Frank O‚ÄôHara

It is 12:20 in New York a Friday
three days after Bastille day, yes
it is 1959 and I go get a shoeshine
because I will get off the 4:19 in Easthampton   
at 7:15 and then go straight to dinner
and I don‚Äôt know the people who will feed me

I walk up the muggy street beginning to sun   
and have a hamburger and a malted and buy
an ugly NEW WORLD WRITING to see what the poets   
in Ghana are doing these days
                                                        I go on to the bank
and Miss Stillwagon (first name Linda I once heard)   
doesn‚Äôt even look up my balance for once in her life   
and in the GOLDEN GRIFFIN I get a little Verlaine   
for Patsy with drawings by Bonnard although I do   
think of Hesiod, trans. Richmond Lattimore or   
Brendan Behan‚Äôs new play or Le Balcon or Les N√®gres
of Genet, but I don‚Äôt, I stick with Verlaine
after practically going to sleep with quandariness

and for Mike I just stroll into the PARK LANE
Liquor Store and ask for a bottle of Strega and   
then I go back where I came from to 6th Avenue   
and the tobacconist in the Ziegfeld Theatre and   
casually ask for a carton of Gauloises and a carton
of Picayunes, and a NEW YORK POST with her face on it

and I am sweating a lot by now and thinking of
leaning on the john door in the 5 SPOT
while she whispered a song along the keyboard
to Mal Waldron and everyone and I stopped breathing

Another sloppy puzzle to complete the weekend. Why do the editors accept this type of slop. If the constructor cannot complete the fill with real words and real (actually spoken) phrases it should not be acceptable.

There weee others I had issue with but I am not wasting any more time on this slop.

4 out of 10 üöÆ

Thanks to @The X-Phile for the Frank O‚ÄôHara sample, and to @john ezra for Charlotte‚Äôs Web. Just two of the many reasons I regularly lurk here in the comments section after solving.

I‚Äôm glad the Mart√≠n Espada and Marsha P. Johnson clues made the puzzle. Personally, I want the puzzle to go political. Everything is political. If you don‚Äôt stand apart from evil, you are part of evil.

As ever - go Gunners! ‚ù§Ô∏èü§ç

Today was the second time in recent memory when this was s clue in the Times crossword puzzle: "Michelle Obama or Jill Biden, in brief." I find it noteworthy and entirely fitting that the well-known and well-established anti-Trump bias of the New York Times should find itself so evident in the crossword puzzle by omitting the current First Lady, Melania Trump, as well as the First Lady who succeeded Ms. Obama and preceded Dr. Biden -- again, Melania Trump. Is it really necessary, Mr. Shortz, to perpetuate this distaste for Ms. Trump? Please leave politics out of your games. Thank you.
My "that'll do" favorites are on Sean the Sheepman's sheepherding videos: https://www.youtube.com/@seanthesheepman5845/videos You can also learn what "come bye" and "away" means.

Sorry not sorry but I was disappointed with the film "Babe". (It's been a while since I saw it, so sorry yes sorry if I'm misremembering it.)

I was expecting to see Babe become a legitimate sheepdog(sheeppig?). Instead he gets a magic word! (Or was it a phrase?) 

Nicky--pictured--was half border collie and would occasionally subject me to the "hard eye".  Like if we were on a walk and he wanted to direct me to  the bush where we once found chicken bones, he would freeze and glare at me. I can see that glare working on sheep. 

That's what I wanted to see. Not Harry Porker and the Porcine Prince.

I don't blame the puzzle constructor for that.
most clever crossword i have ever seen

Thank you to the constructor for the gift of a clue pointing us to this poem (and for his work for refugees, so needed in these awful times): https://www.rosalienebacchus.com/poetry-corner-january-2023.html

We have 10 inches of snow here in my neighborhood. I have to snowblow, but I really don't want to at all. It just seems wrong. But, that said, I liked the puzzle, and used it to procrastinate.  It was a lot of fun. I also remember a mystery novel called, "Pearls Before Swine," by Margery Allingham only because my mother bad-mouthed that book, which was really out of character for her.

VAMPING can occur in any show that involves music. In a music hall show, in a musical interval between theatrical scenes while sets are changed or if an actor misses their entrance. In fact, it now also has a non-musical meaning and a spoken-word actor may vamp by improvising some close-enough-to-the-script lines when someone else misses a cue or if they themselves have forgotten their lines.

@jennie "don't cast pearls before swine" is a saying meaning don't waste valuable materials (which can include time and effort as well as physical resources) where they won't make a difference and won't matter. Pigs don't care about pearls, so save the (valuable) pearls for a pearl necklace instead. 

The circled words all relate to pearl: pearl JAM, pearl HARBOR, pearl ONION. And they're right above the pig-name entries, meaning if you read the columns top down, the pearls come before the swine.

The Polish equivalent of EATERY is "jad≈Çodajnia", literally "the place where food is served". "Jad≈Ço" is an old Polish term for food (derived from "je≈õƒá", "to eat"), no longer used on its own, and "dawaƒá" - a verb which shares a root with the noun-ish suffix "-dajnia" - means "to give". These days "jad≈Çodajnia" is almost always used quaintly, virtually exclusively in proper names of old-school-y, no-no sense eateries serving a small selection of Polish staples, like "pomidorowa" (tomato soup) or "kotlet schabowy z kapustƒÖ zasma≈ºanƒÖ" (thick loin schnitzel with fried cabbage). When I was a kid in the 80s, it was never a proper name, but always a generic one.

@Andrzej Although it may have different connotations elsewhere, in the northeastern US, the term "greasy spoon" is nearly synonymous with the old-time diner, situated in a converted railcar, or built to look as if it was. https://tinyurl.com/tp4bn4wb https://tinyurl.com/2s3umnza Diners are perhaps a bit more dependable these days, but in the bad old days, they were not seen as paragons of cleanliness. What they were was cheap, and plentiful, and available to the working crowd for dependable, familiar fare that was prepared to order but quickly, back before the fast-food joints and the Fourbucks coffee shops took over the landscape. Today's diners are, by necessity, cleaner, but also pricier. They're less expensive than most restaurants, but not pizzerias and other counter service places. Diners' menus are extensive. I'll bet Sam Lyons has read shorter books than some diners' menus. All types of breakfast foods, sandwiches, burgers, full plates of dinner items, including some ethnic fare, depending on who runs the place. (A lot of diners now offer some Mexican entrees, for example, although Greek was the default up until recently, and there are always some Italian items.) And desserts! A display case full of cheesecake, pies, cookies, pastries, cakes, etc., to choose from! And, of course, fresh hot coffee. Diners used to be open 24/7, but few are anymore, but they still keep early and late hours.
